Q2.
Generative art involves creating artwork through algorithms or systems where the artist sets rules and computers execute them, as seen in Harold Cohen’s AARON, which autonomously produced drawings. Early pioneers like Herbert W. Franke used analog systems for computer-generated art. Recently, artists like Dmitri Cherniak and Tyler Hobbs have elevated generative art using blockchain and NFTs. Cherniak’s Ringers explores geometric designs, while Hobbs’ Fidenza is recognized for its organic, flowing shapes

## Data Visualization
## Objective: Create graphics with R
## Title: Fall color
# Credit: https://fronkonstin.com

# Install packages
# The gsubfn package is designed for advanced string manipulation and pattern matching using regular expressions.
# The proto package provides a framework for prototype-based object-oriented programming in R.
options(repos = c(CRAN = "https://cran.rstudio.com/"))
install.packages(c("gsubfn", "proto", "tidyverse"))

# Define elements in plant art
# Each image corresponds to a different axiom, rules, angle and depth

# Leaf of Fall

axiom="X"
rules=list("X"="F-[[X]+X]+F[+FX]-X", "F"="FF")
angle=22.5
depth=6


for (i in 1:depth) axiom=gsubfn(".", rules, axiom)

actions=str_extract_all(axiom, "\\d*\\+|\\d*\\-|F|L|R|\\[|\\]|\\|") %>% unlist

status=data.frame(x=numeric(0), y=numeric(0), alfa=numeric(0))
points=data.frame(x1 = 0, y1 = 0, x2 = NA, y2 = NA, alfa=90, depth=1)


# Generating data
# Note: may take a minute or two

for (action in actions)
{
  if (action=="F")
  {
    x=points[1, "x1"]+cos(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    y=points[1, "y1"]+sin(points[1, "alfa"]*(pi/180))
    points[1,"x2"]=x
    points[1,"y2"]=y
    data.frame(x1 = x, y1 = y, x2 = NA, y2 = NA,
               alfa=points[1, "alfa"],
               depth=points[1,"depth"]) %>% rbind(points)->points
  }
  if (action %in% c("+", "-")){
    alfa=points[1, "alfa"]
    points[1, "alfa"]=eval(parse(text=paste0("alfa",action, angle)))
  }
  if(action=="["){
    data.frame(x=points[1, "x1"], y=points[1, "y1"], alfa=points[1, "alfa"]) %>%
      rbind(status) -> status
    points[1, "depth"]=points[1, "depth"]+1
  }

  if(action=="]"){
    depth=points[1, "depth"]
    points[-1,]->points
    data.frame(x1=status[1, "x"], y1=status[1, "y"], x2=NA, y2=NA,
               alfa=status[1, "alfa"],
               depth=depth-1) %>%
      rbind(points) -> points
    status[-1,]->status
  }
}

ggplot() +
  geom_segment(aes(x = x1, y = y1, xend = x2, yend = y2),
               lineend = "round",
               color="purple", # Set your own Fall color?
               data=na.omit(points)) +
  coord_fixed(ratio = 1) +
  theme_void() # No grid nor axes




Q4.
This chart, showing death versus birth rates for selected countries with contour lines and a zero population growth reference line, effectively highlights demographic patterns and clusters among countries. While the visual is engaging, annotations can be cluttered in densely populated areas, and the lack of a clear title or subtitle reduces immediate interpretability. The chart could benefit from color-blind-friendly palettes, clearer axis transformations, and more emphasis on the zero-growth line. Additionally, specifying the statistical method for drawing contours would enhance its clarity and credibility.

### Paul Murrell's R examples (selected)

## Start plotting from basics 
# Note the order
plot(pressure, pch=22)  # Can you change pch?
# pch is used for different kind of symbols
text(150, 600, 
     "Pressure (mm Hg)\nversus\nTemperature (Celsius)")



View(pressure)
#  Examples of standard high-level plots 
#  In each case, extra output is also added using low-level 
#  plotting functions.
# 

# Setting the parameter (3 rows by 2 cols)
par(mfrow=c(3, 2))

# Scatterplot
# Note the incremental additions

x <- c(0.5, 2, 4, 8, 12, 16)
y1 <- c(1, 1.3, 1.9, 3.4, 3.9, 4.8)
y2 <- c(4, .8, .5, .45, .4, .3)

# Setting label orientation, margins c(bottom, left, top, right) & text size
par(las=1, mar=c(4, 4, 2, 4), cex=.7) 
plot.new()
plot.window(range(x), c(0, 6))
lines(x, y1)
lines(x, y2)
points(x, y1, pch=16, cex=1.5) # Try different cex value?  
points(x, y2, pch=21, bg="yellow", cex=2)  # Different background color
par(col="blue", fg="blue", col.axis="blue")
# overall color(col), foreground(fg), color axis(col.axis)
axis(1, at=seq(0, 16, 4)) # What is the first number standing for? 
# The first number is for the axis, if the number is 1 that means x axis(below line),if it 2 then Y axis(left vertical line)
# the sequence(seq) is from 0 to 16 with a lag of 4
axis(2, at=seq(0, 6, 2))
axis(4, at=seq(0, 6, 2))
# U shaped box 
box(bty="u")
mtext("Travel Time (s)", side=1, line=2, cex=0.8)
mtext("Responses per Travel", side=2, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
mtext("Responses per Second", side=4, line=2, las=0, cex=0.8)
text(4, 5, "Bird 131")
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), col="gray50", fg="gray50", col.axis="gray50")


# Histogram
# Random data
Y <- rnorm(50)
# Make sure no Y exceed [-3.5, 3.5]
Y[Y < -3.5 | Y > 3.5] <- NA # Selection/set range
x <- seq(-3.5, 3.5, .1)
# the density of the normal distribution for a given set of values
dn <- dnorm(x)
par(mar=c(4.5, 4.1, 3.1, 0))
hist(Y, breaks=seq(-3.5, 3.5), ylim=c(0, 0.5), 
     col="purple", freq=FALSE)
lines(x, dnorm(x), lwd=2)
# line width (lwd)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))

# Barplot
par(mar=c(2, 3.1, 2, 2.1)) 
midpts <- barplot(VADeaths, 
                  col=gray(0.1 + seq(1, 9, 2)/11), 
                  names=rep("", 4))
mtext(sub(" ", "\n", colnames(VADeaths)),
      at=midpts, side=1, line=0.5, cex=0.5)
text(rep(midpts, each=5), apply(VADeaths, 2, cumsum) - VADeaths/2,
     VADeaths, 
     col=rep(c("red", "black"), times=3:2), 
     cex=0.8)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1))  

# Boxplot
par(mar=c(3, 4.1, 2, 0))
boxplot(len ~ dose, data = ToothGrowth,
        boxwex = 0.25, at = 1:3 - 0.2,
        subset= supp == "VC", col="gray",
        xlab="",
        ylab="tooth length", ylim=c(0,35))
mtext("Vitamin C dose (mg)", side=1, line=2.5, cex=0.8)

# Persp
x <- seq(-10, 10, length= 30)
y <- x
f <- function(x,y) { r <- sqrt(x^2+y^2); 10 * sin(r)/r }
z <- outer(x, y, f)
z[is.na(z)] <- 1
# 0.5 to include z axis label
par(mar=c(0, 0.5, 0, 0), lwd=0.5)
persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, 
      expand = 0.5)

# 0.5 to include z axis label

persp(x, y, z, theta = 30, phi = 30, 
      expand = 0.5)
par(mar=c(5.1, 4.1, 4.1, 2.1), lwd=1)

# Histogram

# Step 1: Generating random data
Y <- rnorm(50,0,1) # Generate 50 random numbers from a standard normal distribution (mean = 0, sd = 1)

# Step 2: Handling outliers
Y[Y < -3.5 | Y > 3.5] <- NA 

# Step 3: Setting x-values for the normal distribution curve
x <- seq(-3.5, 3.5, .1) 

# Step 4: Calculate the normal density for the x-values
dn <- dnorm(x) 

# Step 5: Create the histogram
hist(Y, 
     breaks=seq(-3.5, 3.5), # Breaks of the histogram are set to match the range of the data
     ylim=c(0, 0.5),        # Set the y-axis limits for the histogram to go from 0 to 0.5
     col="gray",           # Color the histogram bars light gray
     freq=FALSE)             # Display the histogram with densities (not frequencies)

# Step 6: Overlay the normal distribution curve
lines(x, dnorm(x), lwd=2)    # Draw a line for the normal density over the histogram, with a line width of 2




Q2. a)The regression models from Anscombe’s quartet (lm1, lm2, lm3, lm4) share identical coefficients, p-values, and adjusted R-squared values, each explaining about 63% of the variation in their respective dependent variables. This statistical similarity suggests consistency across models but overlooks differences in underlying data distributions. Such differences, critical for interpretation, are only evident through visual analysis, highlighting the importance of graphical exploration alongside numerical summaries.

Q3.
1. PDF: A vector-based format optimal for reports and presentations; guarantees great quality and scalability without damage.
2. JPEG: A compressed raster format characterized by a short file size, useful for online applications but susceptible to quality degradation due to compression.
3. SVG: A vector format that is infinitely flexible, ideal for web graphics and interactivity, and modifiable with vector editing tools.
4. TIFF: A high-fidelity, lossless raster format favored for professional printing and imaging; characterized by an enormous file size.
5. BMP: A lossless raster format preserving unprocessed image data, hardly utilized because of its substantial size and few functionalities.

# Defining the server logic
server <- function(input, output) {
  
  datasetInput <- reactive({
    switch(input$dataset,
           "mtcars" = mtcars,  
           "USArrests" = USArrests,
           "uspop" = data.frame(Year = as.numeric(time(uspop)), Population = as.numeric(uspop)))
  })
  
  # rendering the UI
  output$varSelectUI <- renderUI({
    if (input$dataset == "mtcars") {
      selectInput("var", "Select variable:", choices = colnames(mtcars), selected = "mpg")
    } else if (input$dataset == "USArrests") {
      selectInput("var", "Select variable:", choices = colnames(USArrests), selected = "Murder")
    } else {
      NULL
    }
  })
  
  # Generate the plot based on selected dataset and variable
  output$plot <- renderPlot({
    data <- datasetInput()
        if (input$dataset == "mtcars") {
      ggplot(data, aes(x = wt, y = .data[[input$var]])) +
        geom_point() +
        labs(title = "Mtcars Scatterplot", x = "Weight", y = input$var)
    } else if (input$dataset == "USArrests") {
      ggplot(data, aes(x = Murder, y = .data[[input$var]])) +
        geom_point() +
        labs(title = "US Arrests", x = "Murder", y = input$var)
    } else if (input$dataset == "uspop") {
      ggplot(data, aes(x = Year, y = Population)) +
        geom_line(color = "cyan") +
        labs(title = "US Population Over Time", x = "Year", y = "Population")
    }
  })
  
  # Showing the table of the selected dataset
  output$data <- renderTable({
    datasetInput()
  })
}

# Runnig the application
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

# using iris dataset
irisData <- iris  

# Defining UI for the flower data app
ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Iris Dataset"),
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      selectInput("variable", "Variable:",
                  c("Sepal Length" = "Sepal.Length",
                    "Sepal Width" = "Sepal.Width",
                    "Petal Length" = "Petal.Length",
                    "Petal Width" = "Petal.Width",
                    "Species" = "Species")),
      checkboxInput("outliers", "Show outliers", TRUE)
    ),
    # Main panel for displaying outputs
    mainPanel(
      h3(textOutput("caption")),
      plotOutput("hpPlot")
    )
  )
)

# Defining server logic to plot different variables against petal length
server <- function(input, output) {
  formulaText <- reactive({
    paste("Petal.Length ~", input$variable)
  })
  
  output$caption <- renderText({
    formulaText()
  })
  output$hpPlot <- renderPlot({
    boxplot(as.formula(formulaText()),
            data = irisData,
            outline = input$outliers,
            col = "purple", pch = 19)
  })
}

# Create Shiny app
shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Data Collection
text:
Assignment 1
Q2.

The survey consists of many sections that include questions regarding client preferences, behaviors, and demographics. The way the survey is structured, with questions categorized by several respondent demographics, including movies, DVDs, program, and other relevant categories.



The questionnaire’s struct.ure comprises scaled questions utilizing the Likert scale, with multiple-choice and open-ended questions. The questionnaire encompasses demographics, public views of media content, technological concepts, spending habits about tools, and respondents’ self-descriptions concerning age, gender, and income.


The inquiries address the preferences of media users, subsequently spotlighting issues related to software interest and concern, before transitioning to the topic of purchasing behavior and ultimately revisiting demographic concerns. This explicit sequencing aids in motivating respondents to complete the survey successfully and ensuring that the most sensitive information is collected at this point.

Question 4.

The Diversity and Inclusiveness Survey includes targeted questions aimed at evaluating various facets of diversity and inclusion, concentrating on issues such as race, ethnicity, and gender. Conversely, the Movie Rental Survey is more comprehensive, permitting the inclusion of other topics that may not specifically pertain to diversity or inclusivity. This flexibility facilitates customization according to various research aims, underscoring the custom nature of the Diversity and Inclusiveness Survey in contrast to the open-ended style of the Movie Rental Survey.


Assignment 2
Q2.
a.
Analyzing the Google Trends Data for “Trump,” “Kamala Harris,” and “Election” Utilizing the Google Trends website: For information about interest in “Trump,” “Kamala Harris,” and “Election,” initially go the Google Trends page. Input the terms into the search bar and designate a time window for analysis. Upon the display of the data, it is possible to download it in CSV format. This method offers an intuitive interface for analyzing patterns, facilitating manual examination of dates and interest levels. Data visualization can be accomplished using software such as Excel. b.
Utilizing using gtrendsR Package in R: You may employ the gtrendsR package in R for automated data acquisition. Upon installation and loading of the package, employ the gtrends function to gather data for the specified keywords. The resultant data frame has comprehensive information on temporal interest, facilitating statistical investigation and visualizations directly within R.

library(quanteda.textmodels)

# Irish budget speeches from 2010 (data from quanteda.textmodels)
# Transform corpus to dfm
data(data_corpus_irishbudget2010, package = "quanteda.textmodels")
ie_dfm <- dfm(tokens(data_corpus_irishbudget2010))

# Set reference scores
refscores <- c(rep(NA, 4), 1, -1, rep(NA, 8))

# Predict Wordscores model
ws <- textmodel_wordscores(ie_dfm, y = refscores, smooth = 1)

# Plot estimated word positions (highlight words and print them in red)
textplot_scale1d(ws,
                 highlighted = c("minister", "have", "our", "budget"), 
                 highlighted_color = "purple")



# Get predictions
pred <- predict(ws, se.fit = TRUE)

# Plot estimated document positions and group by "party" variable
textplot_scale1d(pred, margin = "documents",
                 groups = docvars(data_corpus_irishbudget2010, "party"))



# Plot estimated document positions using the LBG transformation and group by "party" variable

pred_lbg <- predict(ws, se.fit = TRUE, rescaling = "lbg")

textplot_scale1d(pred_lbg, margin = "documents",
                 groups = docvars(data_corpus_irishbudget2010, "party"))



# Estimate Wordfish model
library("quanteda.textmodels")
wf <- textmodel_wordfish(dfm(tokens(data_corpus_irishbudget2010)), dir = c(6, 5))

# Plot estimated word positions
textplot_scale1d(wf, margin = "features", 
                 highlighted = c("government", "global", "children", 
                                 "bank", "economy", "the", "citizenship",
                                 "productivity", "deficit"), 
                 highlighted_color = "yellow")



# Plot estimated document positions
textplot_scale1d(wf, groups = data_corpus_irishbudget2010$party)



# Transform corpus to dfm
ie_dfm <- dfm(tokens(data_corpus_irishbudget2010))

# Run correspondence analysis on dfm
ca <- textmodel_ca(ie_dfm)

# Plot estimated positions and group by party
textplot_scale1d(ca, margin = "documents",
                 groups = docvars(data_corpus_irishbudget2010, "party"))




b).The lexical dispersion map highlights shifts in U.S. presidential rhetoric from Eisenhower to Biden, with “American” and “people” consistently appearing but with varying emphasis. Recent presidents, like Biden, increasingly use “people” to convey inclusive rhetoric, contrasting with earlier presidents, such as Eisenhower and Johnson, who made fewer direct appeals.
Q4. Wordfish, a Poisson-based tool, analyzes textual data by assessing word frequency to infer ideological or policy positions without prior knowledge. Widely used in social and political science, it uncovers latent ideas in texts, making it valuable for analyzing political speeches and policy documents..

## JSON method
### rjson

### jsonlite

### Extract the list
govfiles3 <- gf_list1$resultSet

### One more step
govfiles3 <- gf_list1$resultSet |> dplyr::bind_rows()


# Preparing for bulk download of government documents
govfiles$id = govfiles$packageId
pdf_govfiles_url = govfiles$pdfLink
pdf_govfiles_id <- govfiles$id

# Directory to save the pdf's
save_dir <- "C:\\Users\\willi\\Downloads"

# Function to download pdfs
download_govfiles_pdf <- function(url, id) {
  tryCatch({
    destfile <- paste0(save_dir, "govfiles_", id, ".pdf")
    download.file(url, destfile = destfile, mode = "wb") # Binary files
    Sys.sleep(runif(1, 1, 3))  # Important: random sleep between 1 and 3 seconds to avoid suspicion of "hacking" the server
    return(paste("Successfully downloaded:", url))
  },
  error = function(e) {
    return(paste("Failed to download:", url))
  })
}

Q3.

Data scraping faced challenges like inconsistent website structures, dynamic content requiring JavaScript, and anti-scraping measures, leading to incomplete or messy datasets with missing, duplicated, or irregularly formatted entries. While extensive cleaning can make the data partially usable, it may still fall short of reliability and completeness for projections.
Enhancing scraping functionality can involve using advanced tools like headless browsers or APIs for dynamic content, implementing robust error handling and retry mechanisms, and automating data quality checks. Adhering to ethical guidelines and securing permissions can also minimize the risk of being blocked.
